column3: Was there anything else to understand except what was obvious to all the world--a heartless woman jilts a man when a more lucrative chance turns up?
column4: And then, in the spring, to float up to the surface, all horrible and unrecognisable, with your hair fallen out-- Nora.
column5: Rank (with a searching look at her).
column7: The child shall have her way.
column10: Just think how a guilty man like that has to lie and play the hypocrite with every one, how he has to wear a mask in the presence of those near and dear to him, even before his own wife and children.
column12: I can't do it any other way.
column15: I did it for your sake, and this is how you repay me.
column19: But it was often very hard on me, Christine--because it is delightful to be really well dressed, isn't it?
column21: But, Mr. Krogstad, I have no influence.
column22: He was very near his end.
column24: Helmer's refined nature gives him an unconquerable disgust at everything that is ugly; I won't have him in my sick-room.
column26: Nora (after a short pause, during which she busies herself with the Christmas Tree.)
column29: My goodness, can't you understand that?
column30: I have no doubt you have.
column31: I am afraid I can't take credit for that.
column32: Look here; take this letter and go downstairs with it at once.
column34: Nora (with a stifled cry, turns round and gets up on to her knees).
column35: But I have completely forgotten to thank you for a delightful evening yesterday.
column39: Last winter I was lucky enough to get a lot of copying to do; so I locked myself up and sat writing every evening until quite late at night.
column40: How good of you to come!
column41: Do you ask me to believe that you were brave enough to run a risk to save your wife's life?
column42: Your letter is lying in the letter-box now.
column47: May I venture at last to come into my own room again?
column53: Everyone thought so at the dance.
column55: Don't go to him; he will do you some harm.
column58: (Takes the letter, and shuts the door.)
column63: Believe me, Nora, that's the best thing for both of you.
column65: NORA dances more and more wildly.
column67: (The MAID appears in the doorway to the right.)
column72: It was one of those rash friendships that so often prove an incubus in afterlife.
column73: Your skylark would chirp about in every room, with her song rising and falling-- Helmer.
column76: Very well, I will think it over, we shall manage to hit upon something.
column78: You must give yourself up to me entirely this evening.
column79: Nora, Nora, and you would be a party to that sort of thing?
column82: You can do nothing for me now.
column83: I think I have the right to be.
